Map of the USA

I am in a “Mike Bostock” phase and I am pretty much copying him like a small child. However, in doing so I am also learning a lot about D3 and picking up some useful tricks for working with maps. The map above is modeled after Bostock’s U.S. States TopoJSON example. I also followed Bostock’s Let’s Make a Map post to create the topojson files from the U.S. Census Bureau. I used the cartographic boundary shapefiles to get the county and state geographic data. I went with the 1:20,000,000 scale to decrease the size of the topojson file.

Here is an outline of the code - enjoy! 

$( document ).ready(function (){ 

	//set initial vars
	var width = ,
	height = ;  

	//set the maps projection 
	var projection = d3.geo.albersUsa()
		.scale()
		.translate([]);

	// set the path var for drawing the map
	var path = d3.geo.path()
		.projection(projection)

	//set the map var 
	var map = d3.select("#map").append("svg")
		.attr("width", )
		.attr("height", );				

	//use queue to load the json data 
	queue()
		.defer(d3.json, "/assets/data/usa.json")
		.await(ready);

	function ready(error, us) {

		//draw states 
		map.append("g")
			.attr("class", "state")
			.selectAll("path")
			.data(topojson.feature(us, us.objects.state).features)
			.enter()
			.append("path") 
			.attr("d", path)

		//draw counties 
		map.append("g")
			.attr("class", "county")
			.selectAll("path")
			.data(topojson.feature(us, us.objects.county).features)
			.enter()
			.append("path") 
			.attr("d", path) 
	}
}); //eof
